title: How to Restore Electrolytes

steps.headline: Snack on some pomegranate seeds for numerous health benefits.
steps.description: Cut open a pomegranate and separate the seeds into a smaller bowl. A whole pomegranate provides you with a boatload of potassium, as well as magnesium and phosphate! Eat some seeds throughout the day to reap a variety of benefits, such as lowering blood pressure, battling inflammation in the gut, and much more. Bag up the seeds for a quick, on-the-go snack. If you’d like to save time on preparing the seeds, opt for pomegranate juice instead.

steps.headline: Eat a banana to get a potassium boost.
steps.description: Peel and snack on a single banana for a host of benefits. Aside from being a convenient snack, bananas have a lot of potassium and magnesium. As an added bonus, bananas also contain prebiotic fiber, which helps you feel less hungry throughout the day. Bananas also have a lot of vitamin B6, which helps your body battle illness.

steps.headline: Add some leafy greens to your diet to restore your magnesium levels.
steps.description: Restore your electrolytes naturally by munching on a salad. Kale, collard greens, spinach, and turnip greens are all great ways to boost your electrolytes while also satisfying your appetite. If you aren’t big on salads, try making a kale and blueberry smoothie instead. Cooked spinach is also high in potassium.

steps.headline: Opt for yogurt and eggs to raise your daily calcium intake.
steps.description: Head to the produce section of your grocery store for some great, electrolyte-rich food choices. In addition to strengthening your bones, the calcium in yogurt and eggs also qualifies as an electrolyte. Change up your breakfast routine with these items, or eat some yogurt as a snack. Other calcium-rich breakfast options include fortified cereal and certain fruits, like apricots.

steps.headline: Include olives and tomatoes in your diet to get enough chloride.
steps.description: Round out your electrolyte intake with some chloride. Popular foods like olives and tomatoes are rich in this electrolyte, and are easy to add into your diet! Try mixing up a toss salad with these items to easily restore your chloride levels. You can also add seaweed, celery, and rye bread to your diet to replenish your chloride electrolytes.

steps.headline: Prevent dehydration by drinking a lot of water.
steps.description: Continue drinking small amounts of H2O throughout the day, even if you aren’t actively thirsty. With or without exercise, your body needs a consistent amount of water to keep your electrolyte levels balanced. If you forget to drink water most of the time, try bringing a portable water bottle with you to work. Avoid overhydration, as this can also negatively impact your electrolyte levels. Apply the Goldilocks method to electrolytes: you don’t want too much or too little, but just the right amount.

steps.headline: Refuel with sodium after heavy exercise.
steps.description: Reach for salty food and a sodium-fortified drink after engaging in a serious workout. Any type of fitness will leave you panting, but heavier workouts like long distance running and circuit training leave you especially hot and sweaty. Since sweating causes you to lose valuable electrolytes like sodium, salt-rich foods can help you restore this electrolyte more quickly. For example, fried rice with soy sauce and sardines are great sources of sodium. Sports drinks have sodium, but not depending on the intensity of your workout, this default amount might not be enough.

steps.headline: Boost your calcium levels by drinking milk.
steps.description: Switch out a soda or other sweetened drink with a glass of milk. Drinking milk is an easy and thirst-quenching way to provide your body with calcium, a valuable electrolyte. When comparing milk by the glass, keep in mind that skim tends to have slightly more calcium than whole milk. Although there isn’t a lot of calcium in plant-based milk naturally, most products have extra calcium added. Try for a lactose-free alternative like coconut, almond, soy, or rice milk.

steps.headline: Opt for recovery drinks that contain electrolytes.
steps.description: Prepare a recovery drink for yourself within 20 to 30 minutes after exercising. Look in the store for premade recovery drinks that include protein, carbohydrates, and electrolytes. If you’ve been sweating a lot, there’s a chance that your electrolyte levels are lower than they should be. Recovery drinks help your body to get the nutrients it needs in an efficient and tasty way. If your usual recovery drink doesn’t contain electrolytes, try supplementing it with an electrolyte-rich fruit juice, like pomegranate.

steps.headline: Prepare your own electrolyte drink for workouts.
steps.description: Save yourself a trip to the grocery store by creating your own electrolyte beverage. Mix the juice of 1 apple, 1 lemon, and 6 pieces of celery together for a refreshing, electrolyte-rich drink. If you’d prefer a slightly creamier alternative, blend a banana, 1 cup (240 mL) of almond milk, and 1 cup (67 g) of kale together. If you’d prefer to stick with water during and after your workouts, use nutrient-rich food to restore your electrolytes instead.

steps.headline: Opt for more electrolytes when you’re feeling under the weather.
steps.description: Include more electrolytes into your diet whenever you’re feeling sick. Many common illnesses cause you to lose a lot of liquids. In this case, drink over-the-counter beverages like Pedialyte, which are designed specifically to restore your electrolytes and other key nutrients. Whenever you’re sick and lying in bed, have a water bottle nearby. This makes it easier for you to stay hydrated.

steps.headline: Ask your doctor about taking an electrolyte powder.
steps.description: Talk to a medical professional and see if an electrolyte supplement would be a good addition to your diet. If you’re an athlete, it might be a good option to consider. Some brands of electrolyte powder have no calories, while still coming in a variety of flavors!

steps.headline: Get a good night’s sleep each night.
steps.description: Set a regular bedtime each evening and stick to it. Studies show that people who go several days without sleep have lowered electrolyte levels. Continuously restore your electrolytes by staying hydrated, especially before bed! Ideally, the average adult should be getting 7-9 hours of sleep per night. Going to bed dehydrated can lead to other problems, like sleep apnea.

text: Consuming Nutrient-Rich Foods Snack on some pomegranate seeds for numerous health benefits. Cut open a pomegranate and separate the seeds into a smaller bowl. A whole pomegranate provides you with a boatload of potassium, as well as magnesium and phosphate! Eat some seeds throughout the day to reap a variety of benefits, such as lowering blood pressure, battling inflammation in the gut, and much more. Bag up the seeds for a quick, on-the-go snack. If you’d like to save time on preparing the seeds, opt for pomegranate juice instead. Eat a banana to get a potassium boost. Peel and snack on a single banana for a host of benefits. Aside from being a convenient snack, bananas have a lot of potassium and magnesium. As an added bonus, bananas also contain prebiotic fiber, which helps you feel less hungry throughout the day. Bananas also have a lot of vitamin B6, which helps your body battle illness. Add some leafy greens to your diet to restore your magnesium levels. Restore your electrolytes naturally by munching on a salad. Kale, collard greens, spinach, and turnip greens are all great ways to boost your electrolytes while also satisfying your appetite. If you aren’t big on salads, try making a kale and blueberry smoothie instead. Cooked spinach is also high in potassium. Opt for yogurt and eggs to raise your daily calcium intake. Head to the produce section of your grocery store for some great, electrolyte-rich food choices. In addition to strengthening your bones, the calcium in yogurt and eggs also qualifies as an electrolyte. Change up your breakfast routine with these items, or eat some yogurt as a snack. Other calcium-rich breakfast options include fortified cereal and certain fruits, like apricots. Include olives and tomatoes in your diet to get enough chloride. Round out your electrolyte intake with some chloride. Popular foods like olives and tomatoes are rich in this electrolyte, and are easy to add into your diet! Try mixing up a toss salad with these items to easily restore your chloride levels. You can also add seaweed, celery, and rye bread to your diet to replenish your chloride electrolytes. Drinking the Right Beverages Prevent dehydration by drinking a lot of water. Continue drinking small amounts of H2O throughout the day, even if you aren’t actively thirsty. With or without exercise, your body needs a consistent amount of water to keep your electrolyte levels balanced. If you forget to drink water most of the time, try bringing a portable water bottle with you to work. Avoid overhydration, as this can also negatively impact your electrolyte levels. Apply the Goldilocks method to electrolytes: you don’t want too much or too little, but just the right amount. Refuel with sodium after heavy exercise. Reach for salty food and a sodium-fortified drink after engaging in a serious workout. Any type of fitness will leave you panting, but heavier workouts like long distance running and circuit training leave you especially hot and sweaty. Since sweating causes you to lose valuable electrolytes like sodium, salt-rich foods can help you restore this electrolyte more quickly. For example, fried rice with soy sauce and sardines are great sources of sodium. Sports drinks have sodium, but not depending on the intensity of your workout, this default amount might not be enough. Boost your calcium levels by drinking milk. Switch out a soda or other sweetened drink with a glass of milk. Drinking milk is an easy and thirst-quenching way to provide your body with calcium, a valuable electrolyte. When comparing milk by the glass, keep in mind that skim tends to have slightly more calcium than whole milk. Although there isn’t a lot of calcium in plant-based milk naturally, most products have extra calcium added. Try for a lactose-free alternative like coconut, almond, soy, or rice milk. Opt for recovery drinks that contain electrolytes. Prepare a recovery drink for yourself within 20 to 30 minutes after exercising. Look in the store for premade recovery drinks that include protein, carbohydrates, and electrolytes. If you’ve been sweating a lot, there’s a chance that your electrolyte levels are lower than they should be. Recovery drinks help your body to get the nutrients it needs in an efficient and tasty way. If your usual recovery drink doesn’t contain electrolytes, try supplementing it with an electrolyte-rich fruit juice, like pomegranate. Prepare your own electrolyte drink for workouts. Save yourself a trip to the grocery store by creating your own electrolyte beverage. Mix the juice of 1 apple, 1 lemon, and 6 pieces of celery together for a refreshing, electrolyte-rich drink. If you’d prefer a slightly creamier alternative, blend a banana, 1 cup (240 mL) of almond milk, and 1 cup (67 g) of kale together. If you’d prefer to stick with water during and after your workouts, use nutrient-rich food to restore your electrolytes instead. Adjusting Your Daily Routine Opt for more electrolytes when you’re feeling under the weather. Include more electrolytes into your diet whenever you’re feeling sick. Many common illnesses cause you to lose a lot of liquids. In this case, drink over-the-counter beverages like Pedialyte, which are designed specifically to restore your electrolytes and other key nutrients. Whenever you’re sick and lying in bed, have a water bottle nearby. This makes it easier for you to stay hydrated. Ask your doctor about taking an electrolyte powder. Talk to a medical professional and see if an electrolyte supplement would be a good addition to your diet. If you’re an athlete, it might be a good option to consider. Some brands of electrolyte powder have no calories, while still coming in a variety of flavors! Get a good night’s sleep each night. Set a regular bedtime each evening and stick to it. Studies show that people who go several days without sleep have lowered electrolyte levels. Continuously restore your electrolytes by staying hydrated, especially before bed! Ideally, the average adult should be getting 7-9 hours of sleep per night. Going to bed dehydrated can lead to other problems, like sleep apnea.
